title: Is corruption in East Europe high because of the communist regime that used to exist there? - Quora

response.answer_text: Under Communism (I mean Real Communism of the USSR and its satellites, not Marxist fables) the economy produces nothing bur scarcity; it is impossible to get ahead financially through legal means, and the government controls most everything — things that in free countries are auto-regulated through the action of the market are under rigid government control. This is a classic environment for corruption to flourish. As a teenager I had a difficulty passing the driving test. I failed three times. Then somebody who worked in a taxicab company said he can arrange for it. He needed a meal for two in an expensive restaurant and a bottle of cognac. On the next day I was ahead of the line to take the test again; I barely started the engine and I passed. However, in the Soviet Union corruption was abated by fear. People knew that someone, somewhere might denounce their corrupt activities; they may lose their job or even go to jail. Corrupt behaviors usually were between trusted people, between friends. Once the Soviet Union collapsed, the fear was gone. In fact, the call to rapid transition to the free market was understood as simply a call for everyone to exercise his corrupt connections. So, the privatization became a way for various managers, directors, administrators, and, chiefly, various government services from KGB down — to loot whatever remained of the Soviet economy. Now the stakes were much higher: whole factories were acquired through corrupt means. The Soviet mentality in a legal anarchy that was 1990’s was a horrible thing, and while Putin put some brake on most egregious excesses, the mentality has not disappeared, and neither did corruption.  Shopping Without Corruption  Putin’s defense minister’s house in Moscow (Revealed: Putin’s defence minister secretly builds a £12m palace)

Yes, I think it is a long term consequence of been for so long under a paternalistic regime who suppressed individual initiative and without democracy. Then the change to market economy came in a quite abrupt manner and caught everyone unprepared. Those countries had to transit in a few years what took about 200 years for the main capitalist economies. They are still learning how things are supposed to really work.
